verses.text: Now Abraham was old, well advanced in years. And the LORD had blessed Abraham in all things.
verses.comment: Abraham's blessing is comprehensive, showing God's faithfulness to His promises (see Gen 12:2-3).

verses.text: Abraham said to his servant, the oldest of his household, who was in charge of all that he owned, 'Put your hand under my thigh,'
verses.comment: This symbolic gesture was a serious oath, possibly invoking descendants as witnesses to the promise.

verses.text: so that I may make you swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I dwell,
verses.comment: Abraham's insistence on a wife from his own kin preserves the covenant line and anticipates later teaching on marriage within the faith (cf. 2 Cor 6:14).

verses.text: but will go to my country and to my kindred and take a wife for my son Isaac.'
verses.comment: This ensures Isaac marries among those who are in covenant with God, safeguarding the chosen lineage.

verses.text: The servant said to him, 'Perhaps the woman will not be willing to follow me to this land. Must I then take your son back to the land you came from?'
verses.comment: The servant raises a practical concern about God's will and the woman's freedom, reflecting trust and prudence.

verses.text: Abraham said to him, 'See to it that you do not take my son back there.
verses.comment: Abraham is careful to keep Isaac in the land of promise, showing strong faith in God's covenant.

verses.text: The LORD, the God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house and from the land of my birth, and who spoke to me and swore to me, saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land,' he will send his angel before you; and you shall take a wife for my son from there.
verses.comment: Reference to the angel signals special guidance and providence, paralleling later angelic missions (Tob 5:4-6; Heb 1:14).

verses.text: But if the woman is not willing to follow you, then you will be free from this oath to me; only do not take my son back there.'
verses.comment: Abraham leaves room for God's providence and respects human freedom, a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
verses.comment: The oath formalizes the seriousness of fulfilling Abraham's wishes.

verses.text: Then the servant took ten of his master’s camels and left, taking all kinds of good things from his master’s hand. He arose and went to Mesopotamia, to the city of Nahor.
verses.comment: 'City of Nahor' refers to Abraham’s relatives' dwelling place. The lavish gifts show the importance of the mission.

verses.text: He made the camels kneel down outside the city by the well of water at evening time, the time when women go out to draw water.
verses.comment: The well serves as a place of encounter, as in other marriage narratives (see John 4:6-26).

verses.text: And he said, 'O LORD, God of my master Abraham, please give me success this day and show steadfast love to my master Abraham.
verses.comment: 'Steadfast love' (Hebrew: hesed) expresses God’s faithfulness, a theme later fulfilled perfectly in Christ (see Rom 5:8).

verses.text: Behold, I am standing by the spring of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.
verses.comment: Meeting by the well foreshadows future betrothal scenes (Gen 29; Exodus 2; John 4).

verses.text: Let it be that the young woman to whom I say, ‘Please let down your jar that I may drink,’ and who replies, ‘Drink, and I will also give your camels drink,’—let her be the one you have appointed for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown steadfast love to my master.'
verses.comment: The servant seeks a sign, not out of doubt but as confirmation of God’s will, insisting on humility and generous hospitality—a Marian quality (cf. Luke 1:38).

verses.text: Before he had finished speaking, behold, Rebekah, who was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother, came out with her jar on her shoulder.
verses.comment: God answers before the prayer is finished, highlighting His providence.

verses.text: The young woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had known her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar, and came up.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s purity and readiness foreshadow other special women chosen by God in salvation history.

verses.text: Then the servant ran to meet her and said, 'Please let me drink a little water from your jar.'
verses.comment: The servant’s humility and Rebekah’s generosity preview Isaac and Rebekah’s providential union.

verses.text: She said, 'Drink, my lord.' She quickly let down her jar into her hand and gave him a drink.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s hospitality marks her as a model of virtue and kindness.

verses.text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, 'I will draw water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.'
verses.comment: Her generosity surpasses the request, matching the sign the servant sought.

verses.text: She quickly emptied her jar into the trough and ran again to the well to draw water, and she drew for all his camels.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s diligence and readiness reflect the virtues prized in biblical heroines.

verses.text: The man gazed at her in silence, to know whether the LORD had prospered his journey or not.
verses.comment: The servant discerns God’s action through events—a pattern seen throughout both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took a gold ring weighing half a shekel and two bracelets for her arms weighing ten shekels of gold,
verses.comment: Giving gifts after the test shows due discernment, emphasizing spiritual prudence as well as visible generosity.

verses.text: and said, 'Please tell me, whose daughter are you? Is there room in your father’s house for us to stay the night?'
verses.comment: The inquiry about her family ensures the match is proper to Abraham’s command.

verses.text: She said to him, 'I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.'
verses.comment: Rebekah’s lineage matches God’s providential plan for Isaac’s marriage.

verses.text: She said, 'We have both straw and fodder enough, and room to stay the night.'
verses.comment: Showing hospitality, Rebekah acts with practical charity.

verses.text: The man bowed his head and worshiped the LORD.
verses.comment: Immediate worship in response to God’s answer is a model for all Christians.

verses.text: He said, 'Blessed be the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken his steadfast love and his faithfulness toward my master. As for me, the LORD has led me in the way to the house of my master’s relatives.'
verses.comment: God’s guidance and faithfulness are themes fulfilled most perfectly in Christ’s leading of His Church (see John 10:3-4).

verses.text: Then the young woman ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
verses.comment: News of God’s action spreads quickly within the family.

verses.text: Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban; Laban ran out toward the man, to the spring.
verses.comment: Laban’s later significance in gang family narratives begins here.

verses.text: As soon as he saw the ring and the bracelets on his sister’s arms, and heard the words of Rebekah his sister, 'The man spoke to me,' he went to the man. And behold, he was standing by the camels at the spring.
verses.comment: Laban’s responses are attentive both to gifts and hospitality.

verses.text: He said, 'Come in, O blessed of the LORD. Why do you stand outside? For I have prepared the house and a place for the camels.'
verses.comment: Laban welcomes the servant, using a God-honoring greeting; hospitality remains a biblical virtue.

verses.text: So the man came to the house. Laban unloaded the camels and gave them straw and fodder, and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
verses.comment: Foot washing signals respect and humility, prefiguring later acts of humble service (John 13:5).

verses.text: Food was set before him to eat. But he said, 'I will not eat until I have told my errand.' Laban said, 'Speak on.'
verses.comment: The servant’s mission takes precedence over personal comfort.

verses.text: So he said, 'I am Abraham’s servant.
verses.comment: By identifying himself, the servant establishes his mission and his master's reputation.

verses.text: The LORD has greatly blessed my master, and he has become great. He has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male servants and female servants, camels and donkeys.
verses.comment: Abraham’s greatness stems from the Lord, not merely wealth.

verses.text: Sarah, my master’s wife, bore a son to my master when she was old; and he has given him all that he has.
verses.comment: Isaac is heir to both the physical and spiritual blessings.

verses.text: My master made me swear, saying, 'You shall not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I dwell,
verses.comment: Maintaining faith and purity in the covenant community is stressed.

verses.text: but you shall go to my father’s house and to my kindred and take a wife for my son.'
verses.comment: Connection to Abraham’s kin is integral for the promised line.

verses.text: I said to my master, 'Perhaps the woman will not follow me.'
verses.comment: Concerns are reasonable; God can work with our uncertainty.

verses.text: But he said to me, 'The LORD, before whom I have walked, will send his angel with you and prosper your way. You shall take a wife for my son from my kindred and from my father’s house.'
verses.comment: Walking before the Lord denotes a holy, obedient life (see 1 John 1:7).

verses.text: Then you will be free from my oath, when you come to my kindred; and if they will not give her to you, you will be free from my oath.'
verses.comment: The limits of the obligation reveal the principle of consent and freedom.

verses.text: So I came today to the spring and said, ‘O LORD, God of my master Abraham, if now you are making my journey successful,
verses.comment: The servant recounts his prayer, modeling dependence on God in all things.

verses.text: behold, I am standing by the spring of water. Let the young woman who comes out to draw water, to whom I say, 'Please give me a little water from your jar,'
verses.comment: The servant recounts details to establish God’s timely answer.

verses.text: and who will say to me, 'Drink, and I will draw for your camels also,' let her be the woman whom the LORD has appointed for my master’s son.'
verses.comment: Again stressing the sign of hospitality, reminiscent of God’s chosen acting beyond expectation.

verses.text: Before I had finished speaking in my heart, behold, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder; and she went down to the spring and drew water. I said to her, 'Please let me drink.'
verses.comment: God answers silent prayers as much as spoken ones (see Rom 8:26-27).

verses.text: She quickly let down her jar from her shoulder and said, 'Drink, and I will give your camels drink also.' So I drank, and she also gave the camels drink.
verses.comment: Repetition heightens the narrative’s dramatic structure and shows God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: Then I asked her, 'Whose daughter are you?' She said, 'The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milcah bore to him.' So I put the ring on her nose, and the bracelets on her arms.
verses.comment: Nose rings were customary and signified her betrothal.

verses.text: I bowed my head and worshiped the LORD, and blessed the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me by the right way to take the daughter of my master’s kinsman for his son.
verses.comment: Gratitude to God and acknowledgment of His providence is central.

verses.text: Now if you will deal kindly and truly with my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so that I may turn to the right hand or to the left.'
verses.comment: The servant seeks clarity while remaining open to God’s will.

verses.text: Then Laban and Bethuel answered and said, 'The thing comes from the LORD; we cannot speak to you bad or good.'
verses.comment: They recognize God’s hand in the matter, acknowledging divine sovereignty.

verses.text: 'Behold, Rebekah is before you; take her and go, and let her be the wife of your master’s son, as the LORD has spoken.'
verses.comment: Their free consent fulfills the servant’s mission in accordance with Abraham’s oath.

verses.text: When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he bowed himself to the earth before the LORD.
verses.comment: Worship follows the recognition of God’s will, a mark of authentic faith.

verses.text: And the servant brought out jewelry of silver and of gold, and garments, and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave precious things to her brother and to her mother.
verses.comment: Bestowing gifts honors the bride and her family, reflecting the value of covenant and community.

verses.text: He and the men who were with him ate and drank, and they spent the night there. When they arose in the morning, he said, 'Send me away to my master.'
verses.comment: Having accomplished his mission, the servant desires to return, showing single-minded dedication.

verses.text: Her brother and her mother said, 'Let the young woman stay with us a few days, at least ten; after that she may go.'
verses.comment: The delay may reflect a natural reluctance or further discernment.

verses.text: But he said to them, 'Do not delay me, since the LORD has prospered my way. Send me away so that I may go to my master.'
verses.comment: The servant’s urgency reflects trust in God’s timing and obedience.

verses.text: They said, 'Let us call the young woman and ask her.'
verses.comment: Consent is important; Rebekah’s voice is valued in the decision (echoing Mary’s yes in Luke 1:38).

verses.text: They called Rebekah and said to her, 'Will you go with this man?' She said, 'I will go.'
verses.comment: "I will go" parallels later acts of faith by chosen women in salvation history.

verses.text: So they sent away Rebekah their sister, and her nurse, and Abraham’s servant and his men.
verses.comment: The nurse’s presence suggests continuity of tradition and faithful support.

verses.text: They blessed Rebekah and said to her, 'Our sister, may you become thousands of ten thousands, and may your offspring possess the gate of those who hate them.'
verses.comment: Blessing mirrors God’s promise to Abraham, underlining the unity of salvation history.

verses.text: Then Rebekah and her maidens arose and rode on the camels and followed the man. So the servant took Rebekah and went his way.
verses.comment: The fulfilment of the journey marks God’s providence.

verses.text: Now Isaac had come from Beer-lahai-roi and was dwelling in the Negev.
verses.comment: Isaac’s dwelling connects him with earlier spiritual sites of his family.

verses.text: And Isaac went out to meditate in the field toward evening. He looked up and saw camels coming.
verses.comment: Meditation in the field exemplifies reflective spirituality, an ancient tradition.

verses.text: Rebekah lifted up her eyes, and when she saw Isaac, she dismounted from the Sop camel.
verses.comment: The meeting is marked by mutual anticipation and respectful action.

verses.text: She said to the servant, 'Who is that man walking in the field to meet us?' The servant replied, 'It is my master.' So she took her veil and covered herself.
verses.comment: The veil signifies modesty and reverence, a symbol rich in sacred tradition.

verses.text: The servant told Isaac all the things that he had done.
verses.comment: Complete recounting maintains honesty and transparency.

verses.text: Isaac brought her into the tent of Sarah his mother, and took Rebekah, and she became his wife, and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s entrance into Sarah’s tent symbolizes continuity of family and faith, and the beginning of a new matriarch in the story of salvation.
